LAND TITLES BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." Sir, the object of this Bill is to replace the present system of Registration of Deeds affecting land, with a system of Registration of Title. Of the jurisdictions throughout the world which have inherited English Law, Singapore must be one of the last to follow this course of certifying or guaranteeing the ownership of land.

    Last year, the Government succeeded in obtaining the services of Mr John Baalman, Barrister-at-Law and Senior

Column: 570

Examiner of Titles to the Registry of Titles, New South Wales. Mr Baalman is an expert on the Torrens System of land registration. The Bill before this Assembly is his work.

    The advantages of the system of Registration of Title over the present system of conveyancing by deeds are now almost universally recognised. As long ago as 1891, the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council stated that the object of the Torrens System is "to save persons dealing with registered land from the trouble and expense of going behind the Register in order to investigate the history of their author's title and to satisfy themselves of its validity. That end is accomplished by providing that anyone who purchases bona fide and for value from the registered proprietor and enters his Deed of Transfer or Mortgage on the Register shall thereby acquire an indefeasible right notwithstanding the infirmity of his author's title."

    More recently, Sir, a leaflet published by Her Majesty's Land Registry in the United Kingdom explained that the Registration of Title "gives finality".

    The new Register will afford conclusive proof of the ownership of land, by an instrument called a Certificate of Title. The difference between the Title Register and the present Deeds Register is the difference between the positive and the negative. The Registration of Deeds Ordinance, in effect, says, "If you do not register your deed, it will be bad." The Land Titles Bill says, in effect, "If you do register your deed, it will be good." Between the economic consequences of these two effects, there is a wide gulf.

    The advantages to Government and to statutory bodies of having readily accessible evidence of the ownership of land are obvious, but the major benefit will be enjoyed directly by private owners and purchasers. The public at large will also derive an indirect benefit; because when any necessary activity in the life of a community is performed at less expense and in less time than it has hitherto taken, a change must react to the advantage of the overall economy of that community.

Column: 571



    The opportunity has been taken, incidentally to the improvement in the system of registration, to modernise certain aspects of the Law of Property generally, as, for instance, that relating to mortgages. I do not propose to go into the details of the Bill as these are dealt with at length in the Objects and Reasons attached to it.

    It is not, of course, possible, Sir, to introduce a new system like this overnight. The intention is that the present Register of Deeds and the new Register of Title shall continue to exist side by side until the former is ultimately absorbed in the latter. The function of the Register of Deeds will be to feed and gradually to transfer its substance into the new Register until the old one can be safely laid to rest.

    I think I have said enough, Sir, to convince hon. Members that this long overdue measure, which will bring great benefits to the people of Singapore, should not suffer any further delay, but should be proceeded with at once and it is my intention, Sir, immediately after the Second Reading to commit the Bill to a Select Committee. I beg to move.

LAND ACQUISITION (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time." Sir, this is a short and straightforward Bill. It is a temporary measure, which the Government intends to replace at the earliest possible date by comprehensive permanent legislation designed to freeze the values of all immovable property. Government has already secured the services of an expert from Australia who will advise it on the introduction of such legislation.

    In the meantime, it is a matter of urgency that the interim legislation now under consideration should be enacted in order to make possible the publication of the Master Plan for which there is provision in the Singapore Improvement Ordinance. This Plan has now been lying idle for two years owing to the reluctance of the previous Government to enact legislation for the stabilisation of land values.

    This Government will not tolerate any further delay and intends to see to it that the Plan is published at the earliest possible opportunity. There is a growing public demand that this Plan, which will vitally affect forward planning not only by Government but also by private developers, should be brought into the open. The effect of a comprehensive Master Plan, covering the whole island, will be to sterilise some areas for green belts, to allocate some for agriculture and channel development into certain districts. This will mean that some land will depreciate in value, while other land will have its value greatly increased.

    When Government comes to acquire land in development, it will find that the planning for which it is responsible has put prices up against itself. It is

Column: 573

to avoid this that prices must be pegged to a date before values start shifting from one area to another. Compensation for land to be acquired by Government must be related to a date prior to the publication of the Master Plan. Clause 2 of the Bill is designed to peg prices to the 22nd April 1955, the date on which the Government first announced its intention to introduce such legislation.

    Clauses 3 and 4 seek to give the Governor in Council power to acquire land for comprehensive development as new or satellite towns. Doubts have been expressed in the past whether such acquisitions could properly be carried out under the Land Acquisition Ordinance (Chapter 128).

    There are two further matters to which I should like to refer. It has been suggested to me that legislation of this nature is likely to hit the small man hardest of all. Well, Sir, my information is, and this has been confirmed by a leading estate agent in the local Press, that the majority of landowners in Singapore are wealthy men. However, if any cases are brought to my notice in which it can be shown that a smallholder is likely to suffer hardship as a result of this legislation, I assure hon. Members that his case will be given special consideration.

    The other point is this: the fear has been expressed that this Bill, if it becomes law, is likely to prove a hindrance to private development and may even bring it to a standstill. It has been said that no private developer will buy land in future for residential or industrial development because he cannot be certain that Government will not take this land away from him at the pegged price. The answer to that, Sir, is that the publication of the Master Plan should quickly dispel any uncertainty that may be felt on this account since the Plan will indicate what land will be required for public development. And, as I have said before, Sir, the main object of this Bill is to make possible the early publication of the Master Plan. Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

Column: 574



    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak, not merely as a Member of the Opposition whose duty is to oppose, but as a responsible Member of this House anxious to see that the development of Singapore under the Master Plan will be for the benefit of all the people and not at the expense or to the detriment of a section of the community.

    The post-war development of Singapore has proceeded at a tremendous pace, and none of us question the fact that such development without a Master Plan would lead to chaotic conditions which would be impossible to solve within the next hundred years.

    We accept Sir George Pepler's idea that Singapore should have satellite towns all over the island, consisting of industrial and residential areas surrounded by green belts, so that workers will not have to spend many hours each day going to and from their place of employment. We do not think, however, that Sir George Pepler has, paid sufficient attention to the financial aspect, nor has he shown that it is necessary to freeze the price of land to stabilise its value. In fact, similar legislation in England has proved otherwise.

    This proposed Bill is an improvement on the last one in that it fixes land values for the purpose of the Master Plan as on the 22nd of April, 1955, and does not take advantage of any drop in the price of land after that date. Secondly, it is a temporary measure for five years only instead of for an indefinite period. The previous Bill brought in by the last Government was committed to a Select Committee which produced a very interesting report, with three members of the Committee for the Bill and three against; but this Bill has died a natural death with the election of the new Government. Undoubtedly it was this report that has produced the two improvements mentioned by me. If so much improvement has occurred after one report, is it not possible to put further thought on this matter and avoid the freezing of the price of land?

    Sir, I would ask that Members of this House for the time being forget election pledges and look at this matter with an

Column: 575

open mind. Everyone is agreed that speculation in land and fortunes made as a result of the Master Plan should be prevented at all costs. With the knowledge that this Government is prepared even to prevent the operation of the law of supply and demand, he would be a very daring man who would today indulge in operation of land values at this juncture. In any case, it would be very easy to prevent this, and all that is required is a Bill to provide that any increase in the value of land, either as a result of the Master Plan or as a result of the development by and at the expense of Government, shall not be added to the market value of the land if acquired for public purposes. With this protection, there will no longer be any necessity for secrecy to be attached to the Master Plan. By implication, the public already knows that the Master Plan has been in operation for some time, as plans for development have been turned down in the last year or two without reasons being given. I can see no reason why the Master Plan cannot be published forthwith.

    That freezing of land values is impractical is clearly shown by what has happened in England during the last ten years. In 1944, the Town and Country Planning Act froze land values for the purpose of compulsory purchase as at the 31st of March, 1939. This became more and more unrealistic and was finally abandoned when the Town and Country Planning Act of 1947 was passed. Under this Act, a most complicated system was established by which the State in fact acquired the development value in all land, and anyone wishing to develop his land would have to pay towards a fund the difference between its value in its existing state and the developed value of his land. For example, when farmland is approved as a satellite town, then he has to pay the sum of £300 million set aside to meet all claims of owners of land, which has to be restricted in use or development. Much trouble and litigation arose out of this law, as a result

Column: 576

of which the Town and Country Planning Act of 1953 abolished the development charges and postponed payment out of the £300 million, and published a White Paper stating that Government proposed to bring fresh legislation to use the value of land fixed under the 1947 Act as the upper limit for compensation for planning restrictions as and when development of land is prevented or severely restricted. So far, to my knowledge, no new legislation has been passed in England. Therefore, the position in Great Britain is that there is no restriction on the value of land today. But there is a suggested restriction on the limit of compensation payable based on the potential use of the land in 1947.

    Shall we not therefore profit by the mistake made in England and follow the latest legislation instead of rushing into the same position she was in in 1944? Even with all the goodwill of a Socialist Government in providing compensation for those whose land has to be necessarily restricted in usage under nation-wide planning, the scheme was not a success. How can we succeed when no thought has been given under this proposed legislation, not only to large owners, but to owners of small plots of land?

    One particular case comes to my mind. Two years ago, a fire destroyed about 50 huts built on two acres of land at the junction of Aljunied and MacPherson Roads. The owner of this piece of land, who inherited it from his father, was a poor man and his house, together with all the huts on this land, was wiped out. He was getting a ground rent of $250. That has completely gone, and he is now living in a little shed built with the remnants salvaged from the fire and roofed over with flattened kerosene tins. He has tried to build huts and even to lease this land for building low-cost houses, but his application has always been turned down. Perhaps the Chief Minister at his next Meet-the-People meeting can help him?

    Let us take the case of others who have invested their savings in some piece of land and have mortgaged it. So far, investment in immoveable property has been the soundest investment when the

Column: 577

value of money depreciates. When their land is sterilised under the Master Plan, they will not only have to pay interest, but also annual assessment based on 5 per cent of the purchase price. Are such people not entitled to relief? They are now faced with having to part with land at its frozen value, though they might have paid a much higher price for it, plus loss of interest, and payment of assessment. It is not true that only rich owners are affected by this legislation. There are many thousands of smallholders who are vitally affected and whom it is your duty, sitting on the Government Bench, as well as ours to protect. I submit that as soon as land is prevented or severely restricted from development, it should be acquired by Government and compensation paid therefore.

    Recently the Chief Minister announced in the newspapers - and he has been supported by the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat) today - that he has engaged an expert from Australia and that he intends to bring a total freeze Bill which will freeze the value of all immoveable property, including houses built thereon. Such statements made before full investigation as to the workability of total freeze in Singapore are bound to scare away investment, and I would commend to him the wise words of the Secretary of State for the Colonies: "Do not spoil the future of this great place by scaring away capital and investment." Now that he has got his way by the concession granted to him of 'shall' reading for 'may' in the constitution, we hope the Chief Minister will settle down to work and clear the cloud of uncertainty that has gathered as a result of the series of crises during the short life of this Assembly. If he does not produce shocks and unholy marriages, we promise we shall not produce any.

    The Chief Minister: Cannot the Member for Paya Lebar (Mr Lim Koon Teck) stick to the point, Sir?

    Mr Speaker: We are now, on the Land Acquisition (Temporary Provisions) Bill. We are not on a total freeze Bill. Will the hon. Member please keep to the Bill before the House?

    Mr Lim Koon Teck: Very well, Sir. I would also point out that since the liberation some 7,000 families in Singapore have put their savings into home ownership, and about 6,000 of these families have mortgaged their homes to the building societies, insurance companies or banks, and are paying instalments instead of rents so that in ten or twelve years they will be the absolute owners of their homes, free from mortgage. These people are the salt of the earth, as they have a stake in the country and will support a wise and stable government against the forces of anarchy. Are these people to be penalised by having the value of their holdings fixed at a certain price should they be unfortunate to have to sell their homes?

    Facts and figures have more than once been published showing that Government will not be able to cope with the houses required for the normal increase of the population by birth, let alone that back-log required for those living in the slums. I suggest that we should not in any way discourage people who want to help in the development of housing for those who can afford it.

    To sum up, this is a measure restricting the right of free trade, a cornerstone laid by Sir Stamford Raffles when he founded Singapore, on which depends the prosperity of this city, as we know it today. This is a measure recently tried and discarded in Great Britain. It savours of measures shielded by curtains, Iron, Bamboo or Paper, in that the development of the State is made at the expense of a section of the public, consisting not only of owners of large pieces of land, but small pieces of land as well. It seeks to prevent owners of property from obtaining the benefit of any development under the Master Plan but does not make any

Column: 579

provision for owners of land whose property is sterilised. What is required is not a hasty temporary measure, but a full comprehensive scheme so that the planned development of Singapore can be carried out for the benefit of all and not at the expense of one section of the community, without creating uncertainty and fear in the minds of potential owners of homes and persons interested in building houses for people with modest incomes, or in building new factories. Unless their confidence in the future is assured, the Master Plan will remain merely as a Plan to be carried out by Government alone, without the co-operation of the people who are in a position to help in the development of Singapore.

    Sir, I give notice that I intend to move, after the Second Reading, that this Bill be committed to a Select Committee with the object of producing a comprehensive scheme.

    The Chief Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, this measure, which the Member for Paya Lebar damns as a hasty temporary one, has been, it is true, in the making for only two years. I can appreciate that the group, which seeks and needs 24 hours to say 'Thank you', finds considerable difficulty in considering any measure sufficiently mature which has only taken two years of thought. I can appreciate that this group, which asks us to settle down to work, should quite logically suggest that if one report improves a Bill, let us sit down and produce another report, and after that another report, and maybe another report, Sir, and so on ad infinitum, for a Bill that consists of four short clauses!

    It is fascinating, Sir, to consider this speech, peppered with inconsistencies, coming from an hon. Member who, speaking on behalf of his Party, says that it is his duty, as a Member of the Opposition, to oppose - a fallacious theory out of which I hope one day he will educate himself.

    Sir, it has been suggested that we should slavishly follow what England does. Now, I have the greatest admiration for many of England's institutions and traditions of which not the least is this very Assembly; but I would

Column: 580

suggest that we have problems and we have conditions which are perhaps just a little different from England, such as, for example, a little island, an island of no more than about 90 square miles -

    The Chief Minister: 200 square miles! But I think you will find that out of that there are only 90 which can be utilised.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: No!

    The Chief Minister: Check your figures from your Annual Report! Sir, I say in this small island we have to support 1,200,000 people, and I trust it is acknowledged that these are, human beings entitled to reasonable homes and reasonable accommodation, both in earning their livelihood and in their family life.

    The Member for Paya Lebar, speaking for the investment class, says that immoveable property has been the soundest investment that we have ever had. Sir, my late father, for whom I had the highest regard at all times, used to tell me that in Singapore there were two things which were certain to go up. One was a balloon, and the other was the price of land. I would ask you to look no further than my own home. In 1932 this plot of land, on which I rent a house, was sold for $12,500. In 1939, without finding any gold there, that plot of land with the same house was sold for $37,500 - only three times. In 1954, I had the temerity to suggest to my landlady that I was interested in purchasing the house. I was told it would cost a quarter of a million dollars! What had been done to that land? Neither gold nor silver nor anything else was found there! But what had happened, Sir, was that our population had increased, and all a landowner has to do in this country is to sit on his bottom, sit on his title deeds, and the price will go up! No man has a right to hold society and posterity up to ransom to satisfy his extraordinary lust and greed for wealth.

    The increase in the price of land in this territory is something that is quite unbelievable until you examine the

Column: 581

evidence. I would be only too happy if the investors were satisfied with a law, which gave them a five, or six per cent return; but, Sir, on the basis of what we know has occurred in this territory, landowners expect an annual return of approximately 100 per cent. It is a very modest return for these pathetic gentlemen for whom we weep today! In England, Sir, there is enough land to satisfy the needs of its population. In Singapore there is not, and what there is must be reasonably rationed; and in so far as this Government has any power, it will be reasonably rationed, and there will be no crocodile tears for those who have indulged in such fantastic exploitation of the basic needs of humanity.

    Legislation in England is of a totally different character from that which we seek. It is true that we ultimately seek a complete property freeze as of the 22nd of April, 1955. Full notice of that has already been given in His Excellency's speech on that date, and I merely repeat it by way of confirmation. This present measure, however, is a modest and temporary one that says, 'We will take nothing from you that you have got today. What the price is today, that you will receive; and if you have made any improvements to your property and we should require it for a public purpose, you will receive the full price. But we will no longer accept the position that, because of the pressure of population and the consequent pressure of demand which is far greater than supply, you should be able to hold us up to ransom and demand fantastic profits year by year.'

    We read, I think it was in March last, of a very prescient gentleman who bought some land near Paya Lebar for $100,000. That was in 1954, Sir, and in 1955 he made the Government pay him $400,000 for the same piece of land! That is the type of gentleman for whom the Member for Paya Lebar weeps, and asks us to join in mourning as we kill this body of speculators. Let us get this clear: The red herring of the small man is nothing but a red herring. Under the Land Acquisition

Column: 582

Bill that is before you, there can be no question of our wanting to take the homes that have recently been built, and that are being owned by the small man. Those homes have been approved by the Singapore Improvement Trust and form part of our development schemes, and it comes ill, Sir, perhaps it was unintended, that this House should be misled into thinking that this Bill could ever cover any question of acquisition of those newly built houses. This Bill is intended to make it possible for Government in the name of the people to take such lands for roads, for public building as may be necessary, in order to fulfil the needs of the people, without having to pay through its nose, without having to pay such fantastic sums that Government, like the people of this country, will be no longer able to utilise the land for its primary purpose - the purpose of serving the people.

    The Member for Paya Lebar asks us: but what about the poor man who has to pay his mortgage interest? But that poor man, Sir, if he has utilised his land for the appropriate purpose, will be earning enough income to pay for that interest. We are not depriving him of any means of earning his income. We are merely depriving him of the right to hold the people up to ransom. It is suggested that this is a restriction of the right of free trade. This is a restriction of the right to highway robbery in which the people, for whom you weep, Sir, have been indulging for the last 50 years. I can but regret that the hon. Member, who considers himself a responsible Member of this House, should find it possible to attack a Bill so eminently reasonable and so absolutely necessary for the welfare of the common man.

    The first attempt was made in 1949. It was by a Bill called the Singapore Development Bill, clause 212 (1) (a) of which attempted to freeze the value of land acquired by Government from 1st December, 1949.
